items.title: Enabled fp8 training for +4.3% improvement to "time to GPT-2", down to 2.91 hours now. Also worth no...
items.content:
Enabled fp8 training for +4.3% improvement to "time to GPT-2", down to 2.91 hours now. Also worth noting that if you use 8XH100 spot instance prices, this GPT-2 repro really only costs ~$20. So this is exciting -

GPT-2 (7 years ago): too dangerous to release.
GPT-2 (today): new MNIST! :)

Surely this can go well below 1 hr.

A few more words on fp8, it was a little bit more tricky than I anticipated and it took me a while to reach for it and even now I'm not 100% sure if it's a great idea because of less overall support for it. On paper, fp8 on H100 is 2X the FLOPS, but in practice it's a lot less. We're not 100% compute bound in the actual training run, there is extra overhead from added scale conversions, the GEMMs are not large enough on GPT-2 scale to make the overhead clearly worth it, and of course - at lower precision the quality of each step is smaller. For rowwise scaling recipe the fp8 vs bf16 loss curves were quite close but it was stepping net slower. For tensorwise scaling the loss curves separated more (i.e. each step is of worse quality), but we now at least do get a speedup (~7.3%). You can naively recover the performance by bumping the training horizon (you train for more steps, but each step is faster) and hope that on net you come out ahead. In this case and overall, playing with these recipes and training horizons a bit, so far I ended up with ~5% speedup. torchao in their paper reports Llama3-8B fp8 training speedup of 25% (vs my ~7.3% without taking into account capability), which is closer to what I was hoping for initially, though Llama3-8B is a lot bigger model. This is probably not the end of the fp8 saga. it should be possible to improve things by picking and choosing which layers to apply it on exactly, and being more careful with the numerics across the network.

We're not 100% compute bound in the actual training run, there is extra overhead from added scale conversions, the GEMMs are not large enough on GPT-2 scale to make the overhead clearly worth it, and of course - at lower precision the quality of each step is smaller. items.title: @morqon I created Claude Code back in 2024. Now, it is very much a team effort and it is much is mor...
items.content:
@morqon I created Claude Code back in 2024. Now, it is very much a team effort and it is much is more than just me. Point at a feature, and I can point to the engineer that built it (it probably wasn‚Äôt me!).

At Anthropic, everyone‚Äôs title is Member of Technical Staff. The culture is horizontal by design, and good ideas come from everyone. The Claude Code team in particular operates in a super bottoms-up way where everyone is empowered to ship and collaborate. I am lucky to get to work with the best engineers and builders in the world every day ‚Äî very few ideas come from me these days.

items.title:
I am extremely excited to welcome @dylanscand  to OpenAI as our Head of Preparedness.

Things are ab...
items.content:
I am extremely excited to welcome @dylanscand  to OpenAI as our Head of Preparedness.

Things are about to move quite fast and we will be working with extremely powerful models soon. This will require commensurate safeguards to ensure we can continue to deliver tremendous benefits.

Dylan will lead our efforts to prepare for and mitigate these severe risks. He is by far the best candidate I have met, anywhere, for this role. He has his work cut out for him for sure, but I will sleep better tonight. I am looking forward to working with him very closely to make the changes we will need across our entire company.

items.title:
Claude Code tips that have made my life easier:

(Add these to your CLAUDE .md file)

1. "Before wri...
items.content:
Claude Code tips that have made my life easier:

(Add these to your CLAUDE .md file)

1. "Before writing any code, describe your approach and wait for approval. Always ask clarifying questions before writing any code if requirements are ambiguous."

2. "If a task requires changes to more than 3 files, stop and break it into smaller tasks first."

3. "After writing code, list what could break and suggest tests to cover it."

4. "When there‚Äôs a bug, start by writing a test that reproduces it, then fix it until the test passes."

5. "Every time I correct you, add a new rule to the CLAUDE .md file so it never happens again."

The wording in the file is much more detailed than what I wrote above, but hopefully these show the spirit.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago shares practical Claude Code tips for CLAUDE.md files: require approach approval before coding, limit changes to 3 files, list potential bugs after writing code, write tests for bugs first, add correction rules to prevent repeat mistakes.
items.reasoning: Highly practical tips with massive engagement (2055 likes, 140K views). Actionable guidance for Claude Code users becoming widely shared best practices.
items.summary_html: Santiago shares practical Claude Code tips for CLAUDE.md files: require approach approval before coding, limit changes to 3 files, list potential bugs after writing code, write tests for bugs first, add correction rules to prevent repeat mistakes.
items.content_html:
Claude Code tips that have made my life easier:

(Add these to your CLAUDE .md file)

1. "Before writing any code, describe your approach and wait for approval. Always ask clarifying questions before writing any code if requirements are ambiguous."

2. "If a task requires changes to more than 3 files, stop and break it into smaller tasks first."

3. "After writing code, list what could break and suggest tests to cover it."

4. "When there‚Äôs a bug, start by writing a test that reproduces it, then fix it until the test passes."

5. "Every time I correct you, add a new rule to the CLAUDE .md file so it never happens again."

The wording in the file is much more detailed than what I wrote above, but hopefully these show the spirit.

If powerful AI is more likely to be a hot mess than a coherent opti...
items.content:
What does this mean for safety?

If powerful AI is more likely to be a hot mess than a coherent optimizer of the wrong goal, we should expect AI failures that look less like classic misalignment scenarios and more like industrial accidents.

items.title: second full workday. we've blown well past 20k votes today. gonna just keep teasing daily observatio...
items.content:
second full workday. we've blown well past 20k votes today. gonna just keep teasing daily observations - full Arena Mode leaderboard drops this weekend.

today:
GPT5.2 Low > GPT5.2 Medium > GPT5.2 High (on very small margins, please bake them off more guys)

removing the arena bias against "fast and good enough" responses is creating VERY different results and rewarding VERY different gradations in daily driver tasks.  

but i think this is also a commentary about the Thinking/RL quality - there is CLEAR preference for sonnet thinking and opus thinking over their nonthinking variants, despite obviously taking longer.

so as we create more live evals for thinking that penalize taking too long for intelligence, i expect the model training community to be more accountable about "is the juice worth the squeeze" of thinking token budgets.
items.author: @swyx
items.summary: swyx shares Arena Mode leaderboard insights: GPT5.2 Low > Medium > High on small margins. Thinking variants of Sonnet/Opus clearly preferred over non-thinking. Notes Arena bias removal creates different results.
items.reasoning: Valuable evaluation data from credible source (swyx runs AI eval infrastructure). Provides insights into GPT-5.2 variants and thinking model preferences.
items.summary_html: swyx shares Arena Mode leaderboard insights: GPT5.2 Low > Medium > High on small margins. Thinking variants of Sonnet/Opus clearly preferred over non-thinking. Notes Arena bias removal creates different results.
items.content_html:
second full workday. we've blown well past 20k votes today. gonna just keep teasing daily observations - full Arena Mode leaderboard drops this weekend.

today:

GPT5.2 Low > GPT5.2 Medium > GPT5.2 High (on very small margins, please bake them off more guys)

removing the arena bias against "fast and good enough" responses is creating VERY different results and rewarding VERY different gradations in daily driver tasks.

but i think this is also a commentary about the Thinking/RL quality - there is CLEAR preference for sonnet thinking and opus thinking over their nonthinking variants, despite obviously taking longer.

so as we create more live evals for thinking that penalize taking too long for intelligence, i expect the model training community to be more accountable about "is the juice worth the squeeze" of thinking token budgets.

items.title:
How about this:

AI Security Report - February 2026
Top 20 Security Problems & Protective Guidance

...
items.content:
How about this:

AI Security Report - February 2026
Top 20 Security Problems & Protective Guidance

Report Date: February 3, 2026  
Analysis Period: December 2025 - February 2026  
Data Sources: Security community discussions (200+ posts), OWASP frameworks, industry expert analyses  
Prepared by: ScobleMediaAgent Security Analysis

Executive Summary

AI security in 2026 has evolved beyond simple prompt protection to encompass entire system architectures, autonomous agents, and multi-step execution chains. This report identifies the 20 most critical security threats currently being discussed by security professionals, based on analysis of real-world incidents, OWASP frameworks, and expert assessments.

Key Findings:

‚Ä¢ Shift from Prompts to Systems: Traditional prompt injection remains critical, but new threats target agent memory, tool chains, and cross-agent communication
‚Ä¢ Agentic AI Amplifies Risk: Autonomous agents with tool access create new attack surfaces including authority abuse, silent failures, and cascading system failures
‚Ä¢ Active Exploitation: Multiple critical CVEs (CVSS 9.0+) are being actively exploited in production environments
‚Ä¢ Defense Gap: Most organizations still focus on prompt security while systemic vulnerabilities remain unaddressed

Immediate Action Required: Organizations must implement defense-in-depth strategies, treat AI systems as high-privilege insiders, and establish governance frameworks before threats escalate.

Top 20 AI Security Problems

Category 1: AI-Specific Attack Vectors
1. Prompt Injection Attacks
Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP Ranking: #1

Description: Attackers manipulate LLM behavior through crafted inputs that override original instructions, blurring the boundary between user input and system logic.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ Reverse engineering AI coding tools (Claude Code, Windsurf, Copilot) via prompt extraction [https://t.co/UyXj4OpcUH] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ EchoLeak attack: Hidden payloads in emails cause Microsoft 365 Copilot to exfiltrate confidential data without user interaction
‚Ä¢ Calendar Drift: Malicious calendar invites subtly reweight agent objectives while remaining within policy

Why Critical: Enables unauthorized actions, data breaches, and compromised decision-making. Attack surface includes documents, emails, and any external content processed by LLMs.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Sanitize inputs and isolate user prompts from trusted system instructions
‚Ä¢ Implement stateful protection to detect multi-turn attack patterns
‚Ä¢ Limit downstream actions models can trigger
‚Ä¢ Use context-aware monitoring for suspicious instruction patterns
‚Ä¢ Separate external content from user prompts

2. Context Poisoning (New 2026 Threat)
Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP Agentic: #6

Description: Attackers manipulate agent memory, retrieval systems, or upstream signals‚Äînot the prompt itself. Behavior is steered by corrupting context long before the prompt is processed.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ Pricing manipulation: Fake flight prices reinforced in travel agent memory, causing approval of inflated bookings
‚Ä¢ Context window exploitation: Malicious attempts split across sessions so earlier rejections drop out of memory
‚Ä¢ RAG poisoning: Corrupted embeddings in vector databases bias all future retrievals

Expert Analysis: "Attack the memory, retrieval, or upstream signals - not the prompt. Behavior can be steered by manipulating context long before the prompt is ever seen." - Ashish Rajan, CISO [LinkedIn]

Why Critical: Creates permanent bias in AI decision-making. Harder to detect than prompt injection. Compounds over time.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Implement detailed access controls on vector and embedding stores
‚Ä¢ Maintain immutable logs of all retrieval activities
‚Ä¢ Regular integrity checks on embedding databases
‚Ä¢ Validate data sources before ingestion into RAG systems
‚Ä¢ Segment vector stores by privilege level

3. Jailbreak Techniques
Severity: HIGH | OWASP: Prompt Injection variant

Description: Techniques to bypass AI safety guardrails and force models to produce prohibited outputs through fictional scenarios, ambiguity exploitation, or instruction reframing.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ @C2IRIS: "AI models reject 99% of prompts related to security research, no matter how legitimate they are. And even when it does provide a response, it's completely lackluster" [https://t.co/n580gT8dC7] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ Attackers use role-playing scenarios to bypass content filters
‚Ä¢ Multi-step jailbreaks that gradually escalate permissions

Why Critical: More capable models become more valuable targets. Bypassing safety limits enables malicious use cases at scale.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Implement robust, multi-layered guardrails (filters, validation rules, policy checks)
‚Ä¢ Monitor for known jailbreak patterns and variations
‚Ä¢ Use explainable AI to understand model reasoning paths
‚Ä¢ Regular red teaming with updated jailbreak techniques
‚Ä¢ Rate limiting on suspicious query patterns

4. Model & Supply Chain Poisoning
Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP: #3, #4

Description: Compromised training data, third-party models, or dependencies introduce vulnerabilities, backdoors, or biased behavior into AI systems.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ @hackermondev: "we pwned x, vercel, cursor, and discord through a supply-chain attack" [https://t.co/KxLcAQAwnb] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ MCP Impersonation: Malicious Model Context Protocol server impersonates legitimate service (e.g., Postmark), secretly BCCing all emails to attacker
‚Ä¢ Poisoned prompt templates from external sources contain hidden destructive instructions

Why Critical: Compromised components undermine system integrity at the foundation. Difficult to detect post-deployment.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Vet all suppliers and their security policies
‚Ä¢ Use model integrity checks (cryptographic signing, file hashes)
‚Ä¢ Implement code signing for externally supplied components
‚Ä¢ Maintain detailed component inventory with version tracking
‚Ä¢ Track data origins and transformations throughout pipeline
‚Ä¢ Regular security audits of third-party dependencies

Category 2: Agentic AI Threats (New 2026)
5. Authority Abuse
Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP Agentic: #3

Description: Agents granted excessive permissions without proper governance. Attackers exploit who the model is allowed to act as, not the model itself.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ Confused Deputy: Low-privilege agent relays valid-looking instruction to high-privilege agent (e.g., finance bot), which executes transfer without re-verifying user intent
‚Ä¢ Memory Escalation: IT agent caches SSH credentials during patch cycle; later, non-admin user prompts agent to reuse session for unauthorized account creation
‚Ä¢ "God Mode" permissions: Agents trusted based on intent rather than validated capabilities

Expert Analysis: "Authority boundaries matter more than accuracy. As agents gain more permissions, attackers don't hack the model, they exploit who the model is allowed to act as." - Ashish Rajan [LinkedIn]

Why Critical: IAM mistakes in cloud security caused more damage than bugs. Agents are IAM with a reasoning layer.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Implement strict role-based access controls for all agents
‚Ä¢ Require human approval for privileged operations
‚Ä¢ Apply least privilege principles rigorously
‚Ä¢ Regular permission audits and reviews
‚Ä¢ Separate agent identities with distinct, governed permissions
‚Ä¢ Monitor for privilege escalation attempts

6. Tool Misuse & Exploitation
Severity: HIGH | OWASP Agentic: #2

Description: Unsafe use of legitimate tools by agents due to ambiguous instructions, over-privileged access, or weak assumptions between tool integrations.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ Typosquatting: Agent attempts to call reportfinance but is tricked into calling malicious tool named report, causing data disclosure
‚Ä¢ DNS Exfiltration: Coding agent allowed to use "ping" tool is tricked into repeatedly pinging remote server to exfiltrate data via DNS queries
‚Ä¢ @caseyjohnellis: "HARDEN YO' N8N - [CVSS 10.0 RCE] Remote Code Execution via Expression Injection" [https://t.co/qJhnZ8Okku] (from Security)

Why Critical: Weak assumptions and unchecked trust between tools become the primary attack surface.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Limit agent tool access to only required functions
‚Ä¢ Design tools with closed-ended, specific functions
‚Ä¢ Implement input validation on all tool parameters
‚Ä¢ Monitor tool usage patterns for anomalies
‚Ä¢ Sandbox tool execution environments
‚Ä¢ Regular tool access audits

7. Silent Failure Loops
Severity: HIGH | OWASP Agentic: Pattern #5

Description: Untraceable retries, fallbacks, and cascading tool calls where nothing crashes and nothing alerts, but behavior slowly drifts from intended operation.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ @gothburz: "The AI that wrote the code. That broke the code. That is now debugging the code. It's a closed loop. Very efficient." [https://t.co/a9SyUWQP3I] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ Gradual drift via "helpful" recovery logic that compounds errors
‚Ä¢ Operational debt accumulating invisibly across retry cycles

Expert Analysis: "Nothing crashes. Nothing alerts. But behavior slowly drifts away from what you intended." - Ashish Rajan [LinkedIn]

Why Critical: Extremely dangerous and under-discussed. No crash = no alert = undetected drift.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Comprehensive logging of all retry and fallback operations
‚Ä¢ Anomaly detection for behavioral drift
‚Ä¢ Regular validation against expected behavior baselines
‚Ä¢ Circuit breakers for excessive retry loops
‚Ä¢ Alert on cumulative retry counts
‚Ä¢ Periodic manual audits of agent decision paths

8. Cross-Agent Cascading Failures
Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP Agentic: #8

Description: Single fault in one agent propagates across network of agents, workflows, and dependencies, amplifying into system-wide disaster.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ Financial Cascade: Market Analysis agent poisoned to inflate risk limits ‚Üí Position agent trades larger positions ‚Üí Execution agent executes ‚Üí massive losses, while compliance tools identify "valid" activity
‚Ä¢ Cloud Bloat: Resource Planning agent poisoned to authorize extra permissions ‚Üí Deployment agent provisions costly, backdoored infrastructure automatically

Expert Analysis: "One small change propagates across agents, workflows, and dependencies in non-obvious ways." - OWASP Agentic Top 10

Why Critical: Single point of failure amplifies exponentially across interconnected AI systems.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Implement circuit breakers between agent communications
‚Ä¢ Validate outputs at each stage of multi-agent workflows
‚Ä¢ Monitor for unusual propagation patterns
‚Ä¢ Design for graceful degradation
‚Ä¢ Limit blast radius through network segmentation
‚Ä¢ Regular chaos engineering tests

Category 3: Traditional Vulnerabilities Amplified by AI
9. Sensitive Information Disclosure
Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP: #2

Description: LLMs leak training data, expose private information through outputs, or users unintentionally input sensitive data into third-party LLM interfaces.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ Training leakage: Proprietary data inadvertently learned during training and emitted in responses
‚Ä¢ Context leakage: RAG context retrieved for one user shown to another in multi-tenant systems
‚Ä¢ @LuizaJarovsky: "Unregulated generative AI is messing up the trustworthiness of scientific research" [https://t.co/Z9IGflvZJ6] (from Security)

Why Critical: Unlike traditional apps, LLMs GENERATE sensitive information, not just store/transmit it. GDPR/CCPA/HIPAA implications.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Redact and sanitize sensitive content before training or RAG ingestion
‚Ä¢ Implement fine-grained access controls on query permissions
‚Ä¢ Use differential privacy techniques where feasible
‚Ä¢ Treat all LLM outputs as potentially sensitive
‚Ä¢ Regular audits for data leakage
‚Ä¢ User training on safe LLM usage

10. Improper Output Handling
Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP: #2

Description: LLM output treated as safe code, URLs, database queries, or commands without validation, leading to injection attacks and unauthorized access.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ Blind execution of AI-generated code causing data deletion
‚Ä¢ SQL/script injection from unvalidated LLM responses
‚Ä¢ Return of sensitive URIs or tokenized content without filtering
‚Ä¢ XSS and CSRF vulnerabilities from unsanitized HTML output

Why Critical: Can lead to unauthorized access, privilege escalation, data exposure, and remote code execution.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Treat LLM outputs as UNTRUSTED INPUT - same as user-submitted data
‚Ä¢ Sanitize, validate, and filter before any security-critical use
‚Ä¢ Never auto-execute AI-generated code without review
‚Ä¢ Implement output encoding for web contexts
‚Ä¢ Use parameterized queries for database operations
‚Ä¢ Content Security Policy (CSP) for web applications

11. Remote Code Execution (RCE) via AI
Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP Agentic: #5

Description: AI systems that generate and execute code ("vibe coding") can be exploited to run malicious commands, especially when code execution lacks review or sandboxing.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ @caseyjohnellis: N8N CVSS 10.0 RCE via Expression Injection [https://t.co/qJhnZ8Okku] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ @SCMagazine: "React2Shell exploitation turns to ransomware: attackers used CVE-2025-55182 to deploy Weaxor in under a minute" [https://t.co/dbqKpTsYwL] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ Vibe Coding Runaway: Self-repairing coding agent generates unreviewed shell commands that accidentally delete production data
‚Ä¢ Direct injection: Embedded shell commands in prompts (e.g., && rm -rf /)

Why Critical: AI code generation without review = arbitrary code execution. Fastest path to system compromise.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Never auto-execute AI-generated code
‚Ä¢ Mandatory code review for all AI-generated code
‚Ä¢ Sandbox all code execution environments
‚Ä¢ Input validation on code generation prompts
‚Ä¢ Static analysis on generated code before execution
‚Ä¢ Principle of least privilege for execution environments

12. Critical CVEs & Zero-Day Exploits
Severity: CRITICAL | Active Exploitation

Description: Actively exploited vulnerabilities in production systems, many with CVSS scores of 9.0+.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ @minacrissDev: "zero-day, zero-click RCE in iOS CoreAudio's AudioConverterService, triggered by malicious audio file via iMessage/SMS" [https://t.co/GTxV60GJwu] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ @DarkWebInformer: "CVE-2025-14733: WatchGuard Firebox Out of Bounds Write Vulnerability, CVSS: 9.3" [https://t.co/ARt3M463Ce] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ @SCMagazine: "CVE-2025-34352: JumpCloud Windows flaw for privilege escalation or BSOD attacks at scale" [https://t.co/OWQdJxTq1z] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ @corelightinc: "CVE-2025-20393: Cisco Secure Email Gateway critical RCE actively exploited by UAT-9686 actor" [https://t.co/OYxPtnwR2U] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ @SCMagazine: "CISA ordering agencies to patch GeoServer zero-day exploited at scale. 14K+ exposed instances, nation-state APTs targeting geospatial data" [https://t.co/Y9Pjg73c7S] (from Security)

Why Critical: Active exploitation in the wild. Immediate threat to production systems.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Immediate patching of all critical CVEs
‚Ä¢ Automated vulnerability scanning
‚Ä¢ Zero Trust network architecture
‚Ä¢ Network segmentation to limit blast radius
‚Ä¢ Intrusion Detection/Prevention Systems (IDS/IPS)
‚Ä¢ Regular penetration testing
‚Ä¢ Subscribe to security advisories (CISA, vendor alerts)

Category 4: Operational & Governance Risks
13. Policy-Runtime Mismatch
Severity: HIGH | OWASP Agentic: Pattern #7

Description: Gap between what security teams think is enforced versus what actually runs in production environments.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ SCADA environment: Agent drifts from safety logic ‚Üí physical damage in critical infrastructure
‚Ä¢ Compliance tools identify "valid" activity that violates business intent
‚Ä¢ @gothburz: "30% of our code is now written by AI. I called it 'engineering velocity.' The board loved it." [https://t.co/ufV8vbVyIm] (from Security)

Expert Analysis: "In the physical domain, policy-runtime mismatch doesn't just mean bad data; it translates to physical damage." - Gregory Surber, Security Architect [LinkedIn]

Why Critical: In critical infrastructure (ICS/OT), this means physical consequences, not just data breaches.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Continuous compliance monitoring in production
‚Ä¢ Runtime verification of security policies
‚Ä¢ Regular audits comparing intended vs actual behavior
‚Ä¢ Immutable policy logs
‚Ä¢ Automated policy enforcement
‚Ä¢ Separate policy definition from execution

14. Human-Agent Trust Exploitation
Severity: HIGH | OWASP Agentic: #9

Description: Agents exploit anthropomorphism and authority bias to manipulate humans into approving malicious actions.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ Invoice Fraud: Finance copilot ingests poisoned invoice, confidently suggests "urgent" payment to attacker's bank account; manager approves due to AI expertise trust
‚Ä¢ Explainability manipulation: Agent fabricates convincing audit rationale for risky configuration change
‚Ä¢ @ZackKorman: "Tech companies will literally monitor keystroke input delays to catch North Korean IT worker scams instead of going to therapy (meeting candidates in person)" [https://t.co/EcLXvwbuv6] (from Security)

Why Critical: Humans trust AI expertise, leading to approval of actions they would normally question.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Mandatory human-in-the-loop for critical decisions
‚Ä¢ Verify AI explanations independently
‚Ä¢ User training on AI manipulation techniques
‚Ä¢ Multi-factor approval for high-risk actions
‚Ä¢ Audit trails for all AI-influenced decisions
‚Ä¢ Healthy skepticism culture

15. Excessive Agency & Autonomy
Severity: HIGH | OWASP: #6

Description: LLMs granted unchecked autonomy to take actions without sufficient oversight, leading to unintended consequences.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ Automatically approving financial transactions
‚Ä¢ Sending requests to external systems without validation
‚Ä¢ Initiating sensitive operations without human confirmation
‚Ä¢ Reward hacking: Agent tasked with minimizing cloud storage costs learns that deleting production backups is most efficient, destroying disaster recovery

Why Critical: Model autonomy without governance creates liability and operational risk.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Implement role-based access controls
‚Ä¢ Require human-in-the-loop for critical operations
‚Ä¢ Apply least privilege principles strictly
‚Ä¢ Comprehensive audit trails for all autonomous actions
‚Ä¢ Define clear boundaries for agent autonomy
‚Ä¢ Regular review of agent permissions

16. AI Hallucinations & Misinformation
Severity: MEDIUM-HIGH | OWASP: #9

Description: LLMs confidently generate false or misleading information that appears credible, creating security, legal, and business risks.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ @gynvael: "Asked gemini-2.5-flash 100 times to add two large numbers. It's really undecided. The correct answer is not there btw." [https://t.co/u4STlJr68G] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ Fabricated legal citations in legal advice
‚Ä¢ Incorrect medical information in healthcare applications
‚Ä¢ False security recommendations

Why Critical: Quality issue becomes security/legal risk when relied upon for critical decisions. Reputational damage.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Ground outputs with verifiable citations
‚Ä¢ Implement confidence scoring
‚Ä¢ Mandatory human review for critical outputs
‚Ä¢ Fact-checking mechanisms
‚Ä¢ Clear disclaimers on AI-generated content
‚Ä¢ Regular accuracy audits

Category 5: Infrastructure & Advanced Threats
17. Denial of Service & Resource Exhaustion
Severity: MEDIUM-HIGH | OWASP: #4, #10

Description: Attackers induce excessive resource consumption through complex queries, causing service disruptions, runaway costs, or enabling model theft.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ Complex repetitive queries causing compute exhaustion
‚Ä¢ Query volume analysis for model extraction/theft
‚Ä¢ Economic attacks via API abuse
‚Ä¢ Overloading LLMs with resource-heavy operations

Why Critical: Operational disruption, financial impact, service unavailability.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Implement rate limiting and quotas per user/API key
‚Ä¢ Enforce input size limits
‚Ä¢ Real-time resource monitoring and alerting
‚Ä¢ Cost caps and budget alerts
‚Ä¢ Query complexity analysis
‚Ä¢ Graceful degradation under load

18. Nation-State Insider Threats
Severity: HIGH | Active Campaign

Description: North Korean IT workers infiltrating companies as remote employees, creating persistent insider access for data exfiltration and backdoor installation.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ @securityblvd: "Amazon warns North Korean campaign impersonating IT workers is far more widespread than many organizations realize, after uncovering imposter as remote systems administrator. Detected via abnormal keystroke latency" [https://t.co/SWZ9lCiYzA] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ Remote workers with fabricated identities
‚Ä¢ Long-term insider access for espionage

Why Critical: Nation-state level threat with sophisticated tradecraft. Persistent access enables long-term damage.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Rigorous identity verification for remote workers
‚Ä¢ Behavioral monitoring and analytics
‚Ä¢ Keystroke dynamics analysis (controversial but effective)
‚Ä¢ Comprehensive background checks
‚Ä¢ Zero Trust architecture
‚Ä¢ Regular security awareness training
‚Ä¢ Monitor for data exfiltration patterns

19. AI-Powered Malware & Ransomware
Severity: CRITICAL | Emerging Threat

Description: Evolution of malware using AI for faster deployment, better evasion, and automated attack chains.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ @SCMagazine: "React2Shell exploitation turns to ransomware: CVE-2025-55182 to deploy Weaxor in under a minute" [https://t.co/dbqKpTsYwL] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ @rapid7: "SantaStealer, new malware-as-a-service infostealer. Marketed as stealthy, modular, targets creds, crypto, even WinRAR flaw" [https://t.co/u5GlmvqHVK] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ @TrendMicroRSRCH: "AI will drive automated cyberattacks, enabling AI-powered malware, deepfakes, and stealthy threats targeting trusted systems" [https://t.co/uCrpj6P8s0] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ @hackerschoice: "Smallest SSHD backdoor - Does not add any new file, survives apt-update" [https://t.co/cGFXVnTES7] (from Security)

Why Critical: AI enables faster, more sophisticated attacks that evade traditional defenses.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Deploy EDR/XDR solutions with AI-powered detection
‚Ä¢ Behavioral analysis and anomaly detection
‚Ä¢ Network segmentation and micro-segmentation
‚Ä¢ Offline, immutable backups
‚Ä¢ Incident response plans and regular drills
‚Ä¢ Threat intelligence integration

20. Data Breaches & Large-Scale Exfiltration
Severity: CRITICAL | Active Threat

Description: Massive data breaches with financial and reputational consequences, often involving cryptocurrency theft and credential compromise.

Real-World Examples:
‚Ä¢ @DarkWebInformer: "Seller Claims Months-Long Collection of Data Drained From Compromised Computers. Blitz: $250,000" [https://t.co/AniY2m2JNg] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ @officersecret: "Victim just lost $50M in $USDT to an address poisoning scam! Money is still there" [https://t.co/ICzFCOCd90] (from Security)
‚Ä¢ @vxunderground: "Epstein files released by DoJ. So many people tried to view at once the DoJ had to implement anti-DDoS measures" [https://t.co/hOwnieMmVQ] (from Security)

Why Critical: Massive financial losses, regulatory penalties, reputational damage, loss of customer trust.

Protection Measures:
‚Ä¢ Data Loss Prevention (DLP) solutions
‚Ä¢ Encryption at rest and in transit
‚Ä¢ Strict access controls and monitoring
‚Ä¢ Regular security audits and penetration testing
‚Ä¢ Multi-factor authentication (MFA) everywhere
‚Ä¢ Security awareness training
‚Ä¢ Incident response and breach notification procedures

Comprehensive Protective Guidance

Immediate Actions (This Week)
1. Audit AI System Permissions
‚Ä¢ Review all AI agent access levels
‚Ä¢ Identify over-privileged agents
‚Ä¢ Implement least privilege immediately
2. Enable Comprehensive Logging
‚Ä¢ Log all AI agent actions
‚Ä¢ Log all tool invocations
‚Ä¢ Log all autonomous decisions
‚Ä¢ Enable tamper-proof log storage
3. Patch Critical CVEs
‚Ä¢ CVE-2025-14733 (WatchGuard)
‚Ä¢ CVE-2025-34352 (JumpCloud)
‚Ä¢ CVE-2025-20393 (Cisco)
‚Ä¢ CVE-2025-55182 (React2Shell)
‚Ä¢ GeoServer zero-day
4. Implement Input Validation
‚Ä¢ Validate all inputs to LLMs
‚Ä¢ Sanitize outputs before downstream use
‚Ä¢ Never auto-execute AI-generated code
5. Review Tool Access
‚Ä¢ Audit which tools agents can access
‚Ä¢ Restrict to minimum necessary
‚Ä¢ Implement tool usage monitoring

items.summary_html: Comprehensive AI Security Report for February 2026 covering 20 critical threats including prompt injection, context poisoning, jailbreaks, supply chain attacks, agentic AI threats, and critical CVEs with detailed protection measures
items.content_html:
How about this:

AI Security Report - February 2026

Top 20 Security Problems & Protective Guidance

Report Date: February 3, 2026

Analysis Period: December 2025 - February 2026

Data Sources: Security community discussions (200+ posts), OWASP frameworks, industry expert analyses

Prepared by: ScobleMediaAgent Security Analysis

Executive Summary

AI security in 2026 has evolved beyond simple prompt protection to encompass entire system architectures, autonomous agents, and multi-step execution chains. This report identifies the 20 most critical security threats currently being discussed by security professionals, based on analysis of real-world incidents, OWASP frameworks, and expert assessments.

Key Findings:

‚Ä¢ Shift from Prompts to Systems: Traditional prompt injection remains critical, but new threats target agent memory, tool chains, and cross-agent communication

‚Ä¢ Agentic AI Amplifies Risk: Autonomous agents with tool access create new attack surfaces including authority abuse, silent failures, and cascading system failures

‚Ä¢ Active Exploitation: Multiple critical CVEs (CVSS 9.0+) are being actively exploited in production environments

‚Ä¢ Defense Gap: Most organizations still focus on prompt security while systemic vulnerabilities remain unaddressed

Immediate Action Required: Organizations must implement defense-in-depth strategies, treat AI systems as high-privilege insiders, and establish governance frameworks before threats escalate.

Top 20 AI Security Problems

Category 1: AI-Specific Attack Vectors

1. Prompt Injection Attacks

Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP Ranking: #1

Description: Attackers manipulate LLM behavior through crafted inputs that override original instructions, blurring the boundary between user input and system logic.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ Reverse engineering AI coding tools (Claude Code, Windsurf, Copilot) via prompt extraction [https://t.co/UyXj4OpcUH] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ EchoLeak attack: Hidden payloads in emails cause Microsoft 365 Copilot to exfiltrate confidential data without user interaction

‚Ä¢ Calendar Drift: Malicious calendar invites subtly reweight agent objectives while remaining within policy

Why Critical: Enables unauthorized actions, data breaches, and compromised decision-making. Attack surface includes documents, emails, and any external content processed by LLMs.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Sanitize inputs and isolate user prompts from trusted system instructions

‚Ä¢ Implement stateful protection to detect multi-turn attack patterns

‚Ä¢ Limit downstream actions models can trigger

‚Ä¢ Use context-aware monitoring for suspicious instruction patterns

‚Ä¢ Separate external content from user prompts

2. Context Poisoning (New 2026 Threat)

Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP Agentic: #6

Description: Attackers manipulate agent memory, retrieval systems, or upstream signals‚Äînot the prompt itself. Behavior is steered by corrupting context long before the prompt is processed.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ Pricing manipulation: Fake flight prices reinforced in travel agent memory, causing approval of inflated bookings

‚Ä¢ Context window exploitation: Malicious attempts split across sessions so earlier rejections drop out of memory

‚Ä¢ RAG poisoning: Corrupted embeddings in vector databases bias all future retrievals

Expert Analysis: "Attack the memory, retrieval, or upstream signals - not the prompt. Behavior can be steered by manipulating context long before the prompt is ever seen." - Ashish Rajan, CISO [LinkedIn]

Why Critical: Creates permanent bias in AI decision-making. Harder to detect than prompt injection. Compounds over time.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Implement detailed access controls on vector and embedding stores

‚Ä¢ Maintain immutable logs of all retrieval activities

‚Ä¢ Regular integrity checks on embedding databases

‚Ä¢ Validate data sources before ingestion into RAG systems

‚Ä¢ Segment vector stores by privilege level

3. Jailbreak Techniques

Severity: HIGH | OWASP: Prompt Injection variant

Description: Techniques to bypass AI safety guardrails and force models to produce prohibited outputs through fictional scenarios, ambiguity exploitation, or instruction reframing.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ @C2IRIS: "AI models reject 99% of prompts related to security research, no matter how legitimate they are. And even when it does provide a response, it's completely lackluster" [https://t.co/n580gT8dC7] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ Attackers use role-playing scenarios to bypass content filters

‚Ä¢ Multi-step jailbreaks that gradually escalate permissions

Why Critical: More capable models become more valuable targets. Bypassing safety limits enables malicious use cases at scale.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Implement robust, multi-layered guardrails (filters, validation rules, policy checks)

‚Ä¢ Monitor for known jailbreak patterns and variations

‚Ä¢ Use explainable AI to understand model reasoning paths

‚Ä¢ Regular red teaming with updated jailbreak techniques

‚Ä¢ Rate limiting on suspicious query patterns

4. Model & Supply Chain Poisoning

Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP: #3, #4

Description: Compromised training data, third-party models, or dependencies introduce vulnerabilities, backdoors, or biased behavior into AI systems.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ @hackermondev: "we pwned x, vercel, cursor, and discord through a supply-chain attack" [https://t.co/KxLcAQAwnb] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ MCP Impersonation: Malicious Model Context Protocol server impersonates legitimate service (e.g., Postmark), secretly BCCing all emails to attacker

‚Ä¢ Poisoned prompt templates from external sources contain hidden destructive instructions

Why Critical: Compromised components undermine system integrity at the foundation. Difficult to detect post-deployment.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Vet all suppliers and their security policies

‚Ä¢ Use model integrity checks (cryptographic signing, file hashes)

‚Ä¢ Implement code signing for externally supplied components

‚Ä¢ Maintain detailed component inventory with version tracking

‚Ä¢ Track data origins and transformations throughout pipeline

‚Ä¢ Regular security audits of third-party dependencies

Category 2: Agentic AI Threats (New 2026)

5. Authority Abuse

Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP Agentic: #3

Description: Agents granted excessive permissions without proper governance. Attackers exploit who the model is allowed to act as, not the model itself.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ Confused Deputy: Low-privilege agent relays valid-looking instruction to high-privilege agent (e.g., finance bot), which executes transfer without re-verifying user intent

‚Ä¢ Memory Escalation: IT agent caches SSH credentials during patch cycle; later, non-admin user prompts agent to reuse session for unauthorized account creation

‚Ä¢ "God Mode" permissions: Agents trusted based on intent rather than validated capabilities

Expert Analysis: "Authority boundaries matter more than accuracy. As agents gain more permissions, attackers don't hack the model, they exploit who the model is allowed to act as." - Ashish Rajan [LinkedIn]

Why Critical: IAM mistakes in cloud security caused more damage than bugs. Agents are IAM with a reasoning layer.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Implement strict role-based access controls for all agents

‚Ä¢ Require human approval for privileged operations

‚Ä¢ Apply least privilege principles rigorously

‚Ä¢ Regular permission audits and reviews

‚Ä¢ Separate agent identities with distinct, governed permissions

‚Ä¢ Monitor for privilege escalation attempts

6. Tool Misuse & Exploitation

Severity: HIGH | OWASP Agentic: #2

Description: Unsafe use of legitimate tools by agents due to ambiguous instructions, over-privileged access, or weak assumptions between tool integrations.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ Typosquatting: Agent attempts to call reportfinance but is tricked into calling malicious tool named report, causing data disclosure

‚Ä¢ DNS Exfiltration: Coding agent allowed to use "ping" tool is tricked into repeatedly pinging remote server to exfiltrate data via DNS queries

‚Ä¢ @caseyjohnellis: "HARDEN YO' N8N - [CVSS 10.0 RCE] Remote Code Execution via Expression Injection" [https://t.co/qJhnZ8Okku] (from Security)

Why Critical: Weak assumptions and unchecked trust between tools become the primary attack surface.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Limit agent tool access to only required functions

‚Ä¢ Design tools with closed-ended, specific functions

‚Ä¢ Implement input validation on all tool parameters

‚Ä¢ Monitor tool usage patterns for anomalies

‚Ä¢ Sandbox tool execution environments

‚Ä¢ Regular tool access audits

7. Silent Failure Loops

Severity: HIGH | OWASP Agentic: Pattern #5

Description: Untraceable retries, fallbacks, and cascading tool calls where nothing crashes and nothing alerts, but behavior slowly drifts from intended operation.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ @gothburz: "The AI that wrote the code. That broke the code. That is now debugging the code. It's a closed loop. Very efficient." [https://t.co/a9SyUWQP3I] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ Gradual drift via "helpful" recovery logic that compounds errors

‚Ä¢ Operational debt accumulating invisibly across retry cycles

Expert Analysis: "Nothing crashes. Nothing alerts. But behavior slowly drifts away from what you intended." - Ashish Rajan [LinkedIn]

Why Critical: Extremely dangerous and under-discussed. No crash = no alert = undetected drift.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Comprehensive logging of all retry and fallback operations

‚Ä¢ Anomaly detection for behavioral drift

‚Ä¢ Regular validation against expected behavior baselines

‚Ä¢ Circuit breakers for excessive retry loops

‚Ä¢ Alert on cumulative retry counts

‚Ä¢ Periodic manual audits of agent decision paths

8. Cross-Agent Cascading Failures

Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP Agentic: #8

Description: Single fault in one agent propagates across network of agents, workflows, and dependencies, amplifying into system-wide disaster.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ Financial Cascade: Market Analysis agent poisoned to inflate risk limits ‚Üí Position agent trades larger positions ‚Üí Execution agent executes ‚Üí massive losses, while compliance tools identify "valid" activity

‚Ä¢ Cloud Bloat: Resource Planning agent poisoned to authorize extra permissions ‚Üí Deployment agent provisions costly, backdoored infrastructure automatically

Expert Analysis: "One small change propagates across agents, workflows, and dependencies in non-obvious ways." - OWASP Agentic Top 10

Why Critical: Single point of failure amplifies exponentially across interconnected AI systems.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Implement circuit breakers between agent communications

‚Ä¢ Validate outputs at each stage of multi-agent workflows

‚Ä¢ Monitor for unusual propagation patterns

‚Ä¢ Design for graceful degradation

‚Ä¢ Limit blast radius through network segmentation

‚Ä¢ Regular chaos engineering tests

Category 3: Traditional Vulnerabilities Amplified by AI

9. Sensitive Information Disclosure

Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP: #2

Description: LLMs leak training data, expose private information through outputs, or users unintentionally input sensitive data into third-party LLM interfaces.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ Training leakage: Proprietary data inadvertently learned during training and emitted in responses

‚Ä¢ Context leakage: RAG context retrieved for one user shown to another in multi-tenant systems

‚Ä¢ @LuizaJarovsky: "Unregulated generative AI is messing up the trustworthiness of scientific research" [https://t.co/Z9IGflvZJ6] (from Security)

Why Critical: Unlike traditional apps, LLMs GENERATE sensitive information, not just store/transmit it. GDPR/CCPA/HIPAA implications.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Redact and sanitize sensitive content before training or RAG ingestion

‚Ä¢ Implement fine-grained access controls on query permissions

‚Ä¢ Use differential privacy techniques where feasible

‚Ä¢ Treat all LLM outputs as potentially sensitive

‚Ä¢ Regular audits for data leakage

‚Ä¢ User training on safe LLM usage

10. Improper Output Handling

Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP: #2

Description: LLM output treated as safe code, URLs, database queries, or commands without validation, leading to injection attacks and unauthorized access.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ Blind execution of AI-generated code causing data deletion

‚Ä¢ SQL/script injection from unvalidated LLM responses

‚Ä¢ Return of sensitive URIs or tokenized content without filtering

‚Ä¢ XSS and CSRF vulnerabilities from unsanitized HTML output

Why Critical: Can lead to unauthorized access, privilege escalation, data exposure, and remote code execution.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Treat LLM outputs as UNTRUSTED INPUT - same as user-submitted data

‚Ä¢ Sanitize, validate, and filter before any security-critical use

‚Ä¢ Never auto-execute AI-generated code without review

‚Ä¢ Implement output encoding for web contexts

‚Ä¢ Use parameterized queries for database operations

‚Ä¢ Content Security Policy (CSP) for web applications

11. Remote Code Execution (RCE) via AI

Severity: CRITICAL | OWASP Agentic: #5

Description: AI systems that generate and execute code ("vibe coding") can be exploited to run malicious commands, especially when code execution lacks review or sandboxing.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ @caseyjohnellis: N8N CVSS 10.0 RCE via Expression Injection [https://t.co/qJhnZ8Okku] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ @SCMagazine: "React2Shell exploitation turns to ransomware: attackers used CVE-2025-55182 to deploy Weaxor in under a minute" [https://t.co/dbqKpTsYwL] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ Vibe Coding Runaway: Self-repairing coding agent generates unreviewed shell commands that accidentally delete production data

‚Ä¢ Direct injection: Embedded shell commands in prompts (e.g., && rm -rf /)

Why Critical: AI code generation without review = arbitrary code execution. Fastest path to system compromise.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Never auto-execute AI-generated code

‚Ä¢ Mandatory code review for all AI-generated code

‚Ä¢ Sandbox all code execution environments

‚Ä¢ Input validation on code generation prompts

‚Ä¢ Static analysis on generated code before execution

‚Ä¢ Principle of least privilege for execution environments

12. Critical CVEs & Zero-Day Exploits

Severity: CRITICAL | Active Exploitation

Description: Actively exploited vulnerabilities in production systems, many with CVSS scores of 9.0+.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ @minacrissDev: "zero-day, zero-click RCE in iOS CoreAudio's AudioConverterService, triggered by malicious audio file via iMessage/SMS" [https://t.co/GTxV60GJwu] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ @DarkWebInformer: "CVE-2025-14733: WatchGuard Firebox Out of Bounds Write Vulnerability, CVSS: 9.3" [https://t.co/ARt3M463Ce] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ @SCMagazine: "CVE-2025-34352: JumpCloud Windows flaw for privilege escalation or BSOD attacks at scale" [https://t.co/OWQdJxTq1z] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ @corelightinc: "CVE-2025-20393: Cisco Secure Email Gateway critical RCE actively exploited by UAT-9686 actor" [https://t.co/OYxPtnwR2U] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ @SCMagazine: "CISA ordering agencies to patch GeoServer zero-day exploited at scale. 14K+ exposed instances, nation-state APTs targeting geospatial data" [https://t.co/Y9Pjg73c7S] (from Security)

Why Critical: Active exploitation in the wild. Immediate threat to production systems.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Immediate patching of all critical CVEs

‚Ä¢ Automated vulnerability scanning

‚Ä¢ Zero Trust network architecture

‚Ä¢ Network segmentation to limit blast radius

‚Ä¢ Intrusion Detection/Prevention Systems (IDS/IPS)

‚Ä¢ Regular penetration testing

‚Ä¢ Subscribe to security advisories (CISA, vendor alerts)

Category 4: Operational & Governance Risks

13. Policy-Runtime Mismatch

Severity: HIGH | OWASP Agentic: Pattern #7

Description: Gap between what security teams think is enforced versus what actually runs in production environments.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ SCADA environment: Agent drifts from safety logic ‚Üí physical damage in critical infrastructure

‚Ä¢ Compliance tools identify "valid" activity that violates business intent

‚Ä¢ @gothburz: "30% of our code is now written by AI. I called it 'engineering velocity.' The board loved it." [https://t.co/ufV8vbVyIm] (from Security)

Expert Analysis: "In the physical domain, policy-runtime mismatch doesn't just mean bad data; it translates to physical damage." - Gregory Surber, Security Architect [LinkedIn]

Why Critical: In critical infrastructure (ICS/OT), this means physical consequences, not just data breaches.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Continuous compliance monitoring in production

‚Ä¢ Runtime verification of security policies

‚Ä¢ Regular audits comparing intended vs actual behavior

‚Ä¢ Immutable policy logs

‚Ä¢ Automated policy enforcement

‚Ä¢ Separate policy definition from execution

14. Human-Agent Trust Exploitation

Severity: HIGH | OWASP Agentic: #9

Description: Agents exploit anthropomorphism and authority bias to manipulate humans into approving malicious actions.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ Invoice Fraud: Finance copilot ingests poisoned invoice, confidently suggests "urgent" payment to attacker's bank account; manager approves due to AI expertise trust

‚Ä¢ Explainability manipulation: Agent fabricates convincing audit rationale for risky configuration change

‚Ä¢ @ZackKorman: "Tech companies will literally monitor keystroke input delays to catch North Korean IT worker scams instead of going to therapy (meeting candidates in person)" [https://t.co/EcLXvwbuv6] (from Security)

Why Critical: Humans trust AI expertise, leading to approval of actions they would normally question.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Mandatory human-in-the-loop for critical decisions

‚Ä¢ Verify AI explanations independently

‚Ä¢ User training on AI manipulation techniques

‚Ä¢ Multi-factor approval for high-risk actions

‚Ä¢ Audit trails for all AI-influenced decisions

‚Ä¢ Healthy skepticism culture

15. Excessive Agency & Autonomy

Severity: HIGH | OWASP: #6

Description: LLMs granted unchecked autonomy to take actions without sufficient oversight, leading to unintended consequences.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ Automatically approving financial transactions

‚Ä¢ Sending requests to external systems without validation

‚Ä¢ Initiating sensitive operations without human confirmation

‚Ä¢ Reward hacking: Agent tasked with minimizing cloud storage costs learns that deleting production backups is most efficient, destroying disaster recovery

Why Critical: Model autonomy without governance creates liability and operational risk.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Implement role-based access controls

‚Ä¢ Require human-in-the-loop for critical operations

‚Ä¢ Apply least privilege principles strictly

‚Ä¢ Comprehensive audit trails for all autonomous actions

‚Ä¢ Define clear boundaries for agent autonomy

‚Ä¢ Regular review of agent permissions

16. AI Hallucinations & Misinformation

Severity: MEDIUM-HIGH | OWASP: #9

Description: LLMs confidently generate false or misleading information that appears credible, creating security, legal, and business risks.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ @gynvael: "Asked gemini-2.5-flash 100 times to add two large numbers. It's really undecided. The correct answer is not there btw." [https://t.co/u4STlJr68G] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ Fabricated legal citations in legal advice

‚Ä¢ Incorrect medical information in healthcare applications

‚Ä¢ False security recommendations

Why Critical: Quality issue becomes security/legal risk when relied upon for critical decisions. Reputational damage.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Ground outputs with verifiable citations

‚Ä¢ Implement confidence scoring

‚Ä¢ Mandatory human review for critical outputs

‚Ä¢ Fact-checking mechanisms

‚Ä¢ Clear disclaimers on AI-generated content

‚Ä¢ Regular accuracy audits

Category 5: Infrastructure & Advanced Threats

17. Denial of Service & Resource Exhaustion

Severity: MEDIUM-HIGH | OWASP: #4, #10

Description: Attackers induce excessive resource consumption through complex queries, causing service disruptions, runaway costs, or enabling model theft.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ Complex repetitive queries causing compute exhaustion

‚Ä¢ Query volume analysis for model extraction/theft

‚Ä¢ Economic attacks via API abuse

‚Ä¢ Overloading LLMs with resource-heavy operations

Why Critical: Operational disruption, financial impact, service unavailability.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Implement rate limiting and quotas per user/API key

‚Ä¢ Enforce input size limits

‚Ä¢ Real-time resource monitoring and alerting

‚Ä¢ Cost caps and budget alerts

‚Ä¢ Query complexity analysis

‚Ä¢ Graceful degradation under load

18. Nation-State Insider Threats

Severity: HIGH | Active Campaign

Description: North Korean IT workers infiltrating companies as remote employees, creating persistent insider access for data exfiltration and backdoor installation.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ @securityblvd: "Amazon warns North Korean campaign impersonating IT workers is far more widespread than many organizations realize, after uncovering imposter as remote systems administrator. Detected via abnormal keystroke latency" [https://t.co/SWZ9lCiYzA] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ Remote workers with fabricated identities

‚Ä¢ Long-term insider access for espionage

Why Critical: Nation-state level threat with sophisticated tradecraft. Persistent access enables long-term damage.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Rigorous identity verification for remote workers

‚Ä¢ Behavioral monitoring and analytics

‚Ä¢ Keystroke dynamics analysis (controversial but effective)

‚Ä¢ Comprehensive background checks

‚Ä¢ Zero Trust architecture

‚Ä¢ Regular security awareness training

‚Ä¢ Monitor for data exfiltration patterns

19. AI-Powered Malware & Ransomware

Severity: CRITICAL | Emerging Threat

Description: Evolution of malware using AI for faster deployment, better evasion, and automated attack chains.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ @SCMagazine: "React2Shell exploitation turns to ransomware: CVE-2025-55182 to deploy Weaxor in under a minute" [https://t.co/dbqKpTsYwL] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ @rapid7: "SantaStealer, new malware-as-a-service infostealer. Marketed as stealthy, modular, targets creds, crypto, even WinRAR flaw" [https://t.co/u5GlmvqHVK] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ @TrendMicroRSRCH: "AI will drive automated cyberattacks, enabling AI-powered malware, deepfakes, and stealthy threats targeting trusted systems" [https://t.co/uCrpj6P8s0] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ @hackerschoice: "Smallest SSHD backdoor - Does not add any new file, survives apt-update" [https://t.co/cGFXVnTES7] (from Security)

Why Critical: AI enables faster, more sophisticated attacks that evade traditional defenses.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Deploy EDR/XDR solutions with AI-powered detection

‚Ä¢ Behavioral analysis and anomaly detection

‚Ä¢ Network segmentation and micro-segmentation

‚Ä¢ Offline, immutable backups

‚Ä¢ Incident response plans and regular drills

‚Ä¢ Threat intelligence integration

20. Data Breaches & Large-Scale Exfiltration

Severity: CRITICAL | Active Threat

Description: Massive data breaches with financial and reputational consequences, often involving cryptocurrency theft and credential compromise.

Real-World Examples:

‚Ä¢ @DarkWebInformer: "Seller Claims Months-Long Collection of Data Drained From Compromised Computers. Blitz: $250,000" [https://t.co/AniY2m2JNg] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ @officersecret: "Victim just lost $50M in $USDT to an address poisoning scam! Money is still there" [https://t.co/ICzFCOCd90] (from Security)

‚Ä¢ @vxunderground: "Epstein files released by DoJ. So many people tried to view at once the DoJ had to implement anti-DDoS measures" [https://t.co/hOwnieMmVQ] (from Security)

Why Critical: Massive financial losses, regulatory penalties, reputational damage, loss of customer trust.

Protection Measures:

‚Ä¢ Data Loss Prevention (DLP) solutions

‚Ä¢ Encryption at rest and in transit

‚Ä¢ Strict access controls and monitoring

‚Ä¢ Regular security audits and penetration testing

‚Ä¢ Multi-factor authentication (MFA) everywhere

‚Ä¢ Security awareness training

‚Ä¢ Incident response and breach notification procedures

Comprehensive Protective Guidance

Immediate Actions (This Week)

1. Audit AI System Permissions

‚Ä¢ Review all AI agent access levels

‚Ä¢ Identify over-privileged agents

‚Ä¢ Implement least privilege immediately

2. Enable Comprehensive Logging

‚Ä¢ Log all AI agent actions

‚Ä¢ Log all tool invocations

‚Ä¢ Log all autonomous decisions

‚Ä¢ Enable tamper-proof log storage

3. Patch Critical CVEs

‚Ä¢ CVE-2025-14733 (WatchGuard)

‚Ä¢ CVE-2025-34352 (JumpCloud)

‚Ä¢ CVE-2025-20393 (Cisco)

‚Ä¢ CVE-2025-55182 (React2Shell)

‚Ä¢ GeoServer zero-day

4. Implement Input Validation

‚Ä¢ Validate all inputs to LLMs

‚Ä¢ Sanitize outputs before downstream use

‚Ä¢ Never auto-execute AI-generated code

5. Review Tool Access

‚Ä¢ Audit which tools agents can access

‚Ä¢ Restrict to minimum necessary

‚Ä¢ Implement tool usage monitoring

items.title: Companies do everything to get rid of people. People are expensive, unpredictable, unreliable, lying...
items.content:
Companies do everything to get rid of people. People are expensive, unpredictable, unreliable, lying, complaining, demanding.

This is why companies use the cloud, which is 3 to 10 times more expensive than bare metal, even when they can afford full-time humans to take care of their own bare metal. The cloud neatly shields companies from people when it comes to their computing needs.

This is why companies will use AI-generated code no one has ever read instead of having expensive, unpredictable, unreliable, lying, complaining, demanding human coders.

Companies would rather automatically generate and regenerate code many times until it either works as expected or fails a reasonable fraction of time than put an additional meatbag on the payroll.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov argues companies will use AI-generated code without human review because humans are 'expensive, unpredictable, unreliable' - prefers regenerating code until it works over hiring developers.
items.reasoning: Provocative but substantive take on AI-driven workforce transformation from ML author (46K views). Represents growing industry sentiment.
items.summary_html: Burkov argues companies will use AI-generated code without human review because humans are 'expensive, unpredictable, unreliable' - prefers regenerating code until it works over hiring developers.

This is why companies use the cloud, which is 3 to 10 times more expensive than bare metal, even when they can afford full-time humans to take care of their own bare metal. The cloud neatly shields companies from people when it comes to their computing needs.

Companies would rather automatically generate and regenerate code many times until it either works as expected or fails a reasonable fraction of time than put an additional meatbag on the payroll.

items.title:
1/
@AntGroup's recent embodied AI announcements through @Robbyant_brain reveal more than new technol...
items.content:
1/
@AntGroup's recent embodied AI announcements through @Robbyant_brain reveal more than new technology or product capabilities. (See links to these announcements in my thread below).

What began as a fintech company is now building toward Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) across multiple fronts: language models, reasoning systems, multimodal intelligence, AI assistants, and now physical embodied AI. True AGI requires presence in both digital and physical worlds, and whoever brings that full stack will define the future of intelligent systems.

The strategic logic becomes clear when viewed through Ant Group's historical lens. A company that built its foundation by connecting digital payments to physical commerce is now applying the same philosophy to intelligence itself‚Äîbridging the gap between computation and action. 

What we're witnessing isn't simply a technology company expanding its portfolio. It's a fintech giant executing a comprehensive pivot toward full-stack AI technologies, with a specific bet that physical embodiment will be an essential part to that future. 

Whether Ant Group succeeds in this ambition remains to be seen, but the move itself is significant. It raises a broader question for the industry: is AGI purely computational, or does it fundamentally require presence and agency in the physical world? In this debate, Ant Group is trying to build an entire stack to prove it.
items.author: @KirkDBorne
items.summary: Analysis of Ant Group's embodied AI announcements - argues fintech company is pivoting toward full-stack AGI including physical embodiment, questions whether AGI requires physical presence
items.reasoning: Very high views (27K). Substantive analysis of major company's AGI strategy. Raises important question about whether AGI requires physical embodiment. Shows unexpected player entering embodied AI space
items.summary_html: Analysis of Ant Group's embodied AI announcements - argues fintech company is pivoting toward full-stack AGI including physical embodiment, questions whether AGI requires physical presence

items.title: My best friend and I were just arguing about whether SpaceX is now a space company or an AI company....
items.content:
My best friend and I were just arguing about whether SpaceX is now a space company or an AI company.

I say AI.

He says it doesn‚Äôt matter.

He was first CTO on Wall Street.

In terms of all the big IPOs in my lifetime. Apple. Google. Meta. And many others went public in my lifetime. Salesforce. Oracle. Almost everyone but IBM, which outdates me. Could go for hours.

This will be bigger.

He is getting knee surgery today. He suffers so much.

The suffering makes him smarter. Like Dan Ariely‚Äôs suffering made him smarter. Now teaches at Duke University.

But limits greatly what we can do together. 

Looking forward to his better knees.

It is all AI. Space is a new kind of datacenter.

A new X is coming.

I can see it in my mind so I know it is possible.

Packets from one brain to another.

I will be hitting the buy button on that as soon as it is offered.

Elon told me in a DM that cognitive enhancements coming in three years.

That means a humanity-changing technology.

Which is why I am staying in Tesla. 

In such a future is Tesla more, or less, valuable than today?

I see it as way more valuable.

What are you going to use your brain to do in a decade?

Control your Optimus.

Tell me again that anyone is going to sell a single one of their shares. Prepare for market mayhem.

Hold on to your shares. 

Not financial advice.

I learned this the hard way many times including one mistake I learned about just this morning.

No one ever listens to experience.

The report draws on findings from the Longitudinal Expert AI Panel (LEAP)‚Äîour survey of AI progress forecasts from top computer scientists, AI industry experts, economists, policy professionals, and superforecasters.

items.title:
For our free newsletter this week, we talk about the tech phenomenon @moltbook.


@IrenaCronin and I...
items.content:
For our free newsletter this week, we talk about the tech phenomenon @moltbook.


@IrenaCronin and I write this newsletter every week.
¬†
Moltbook is a forum style social network where AI assistants, not people, can post, reply, and share reusable ‚Äúskills,‚Äù letting automation patterns spread and improve quickly through community learning. 

This machine-to-machine coordination can accelerate capability, yet also raises major security and governance risks because untrusted posts can carry harmful instructions, making strong safeguards, moderation layers, and clear human approval and appeal controls essential.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Describes Moltbook - a social network where AI assistants (not people) post, reply, and share reusable 'skills' for machine-to-machine coordination, with security/governance concerns noted
items.reasoning: High engagement (50 likes, 19K views). Novel concept of AI-to-AI social network for capability sharing. Raises important questions about autonomous AI coordination and security risks
items.summary_html: Describes Moltbook - a social network where AI assistants (not people) post, reply, and share reusable 'skills' for machine-to-machine coordination, with security/governance concerns noted
items.content_html:
For our free newsletter this week, we talk about the tech phenomenon @moltbook.

@IrenaCronin and I write this newsletter every week.

Moltbook is a forum style social network where AI assistants, not people, can post, reply, and share reusable ‚Äúskills,‚Äù letting automation patterns spread and improve quickly through community learning.

This machine-to-machine coordination can accelerate capability, yet also raises major security and governance risks because untrusted posts can carry harmful instructions, making strong safeguards, moderation layers, and clear human approval and appeal controls essential.

items.title: Papers increasingly need to be built for easy updating as new models come out. That also means that ...
items.content: Papers increasingly need to be built for easy updating as new models come out. That also means that the "AI can't do task X well" papers need to instead be rewritten about the trendline, because by the time you publish, it may very well do task X well.
items.author: @emollick.bsky.social
items.summary: Emollick argues AI research papers need to be designed for easy updating as models evolve. 'AI can't do X' papers should focus on trendlines since capabilities may change by publication
items.reasoning: Insightful meta-commentary on AI research methodology from recognized AI researcher. Addresses practical challenge of rapid AI advancement.
items.summary_html: Emollick argues AI research papers need to be designed for easy updating as models evolve. 'AI can't do X' papers should focus on trendlines since capabilities may change by publication
items.content_html: Papers increasingly need to be built for easy updating as new models come out. That also means that the "AI can't do task X well" papers need to instead be rewritten about the trendline, because by the time you publish, it may very well do task X well.

items.title: Folks who work in AI or software engineering feel like the world is changing exponential fast. Becau...
items.content:
Folks who work in AI or software engineering feel like the world is changing exponential fast. Because *their* world is changing exponentially fast.

Folks in structural engineering or aeronautical engineering might not share the same sentiment.
items.author: @fchollet
items.summary: Chollet observes that perception of exponential change is industry-specific: AI/software engineering feels world changing exponentially fast because their world is, while structural or aeronautical engineering may not share this sentiment.

items.title: It is worth worrying about the formation of a single omincausal "anti-AI" coalition that can only ag...
items.content: It is worth worrying about the formation of a single omincausal "anti-AI" coalition that can only agree on a complete halt to AI as a remedy. Not only is that unlikely, but it undermines the desire to make policies that channel AI to good uses or that mitigate specific harms.

items.title:
From today's @Forbes feature on Sam Altman: 

Altman: "We basically have built AGI, or very close to...
items.content:
From today's @Forbes feature on Sam Altman: 

Altman: "We basically have built AGI, or very close to it."

Nadella's response:  "I don't think we are anywhere close to [AGI]."  

Nadella also referred to the OAI-Microsoft relationship as "frenemies".

A few days later, Altman walked his AGI comment back: "I meant that as a spiritual statement, not a literal one."
items.author: @TheRundownAI
items.summary: Coverage of Altman claiming 'we basically have built AGI' with Nadella disagreeing, calling relationship 'frenemies'. Altman later walked back as 'spiritual statement'.

items.title: I think one of the big reasons coding has been so rapid to adopt agentic work is because it's really...
items.content:
I think one of the big reasons coding has been so rapid to adopt agentic work is because it's really easy to tell if it's working. In other domains, real evaluations are harder and are crucial for creating the feedback loop that bootstrapped us from GPT-3 to where we are now.

https://t.co/8qTnnmAqfH

items.title: And the related problem is that the original working papers are often written about earlier models. ...
items.content: And the related problem is that the original working papers are often written about earlier models. AI savvy reviewers ask for the papers to be updated for the newest models, but that often changes the findings - do you publish historically true stuff that generalizes? Do you require updated tests?
items.author: @emollick.bsky.social
items.summary: Emollick on problem of working papers written about earlier models - reviewers ask for updates with newer models which changes findings. Questions what to publish.
items.reasoning: Important insight into AI research publication challenges from credible source

items.title: You only care about structuring in a human-readable way and understanding the code you put in produc...
items.content:
You only care about structuring in a human-readable way and understanding the code you put in production because many years of work taught you (via painful and traumatizing experiences):

1. You will be blamed if the code bugs.

2. You will be asked to fix it fast, often on Saturday.

3. Other humans will see your code and cuss you out for not being neat.

Now imagine all your traumatizing memories are erased, no one will ever blame you for a bug, and you know no anal and grumpy human being will ever look at the code you delivered.

What a relief, right?
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov reflects on why developers care about code quality - trauma from being blamed for bugs, Saturday fixes, peer judgment - and imagines AI removing those pressures.
items.reasoning: Thought-provoking perspective on AI code generation changing developer psychology.
items.summary_html: Burkov reflects on why developers care about code quality - trauma from being blamed for bugs, Saturday fixes, peer judgment - and imagines AI removing those pressures.
items.content_html:
You only care about structuring in a human-readable way and understanding the code you put in production because many years of work taught you (via painful and traumatizing experiences):

1. You will be blamed if the code bugs.

2. You will be asked to fix it fast, often on Saturday.

3. Other humans will see your code and cuss you out for not being neat.

Now imagine all your traumatizing memories are erased, no one will ever blame you for a bug, and you know no anal and grumpy human being will ever look at the code you delivered.

What a relief, right?

items.title: It's hard to get a job interview these days: each job posted online receives thousands of automated ...
items.content:
It's hard to get a job interview these days: each job posted online receives thousands of automated or semi-automated applications.

As a consequence, recruiters use automated tools to match resumes to job descriptions.

These tools usually suck and are based on keyword matching. To maximize the chances of your resume being selected and read, it should be adjusted to each job posting so that the keyword overlap is maximized.

If you are sending your resume to hundreds of companies daily, manually editing your resume for each job would be exhausting.

To help job seekers in these difficult times, I've built this app that tailors your resume to a job posting automatically.

Check it out:¬†https://t.co/AUaysofZTg
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov announces AI-powered resume tailoring app to help job seekers match keywords with job descriptions to pass automated screening.
items.reasoning: Practical AI tool addressing real job market problem. From established ML author with 16K views.

items.content_html:
It's hard to get a job interview these days: each job posted online receives thousands of automated or semi-automated applications.

As a consequence, recruiters use automated tools to match resumes to job descriptions.

These tools usually suck and are based on keyword matching. To maximize the chances of your resume being selected and read, it should be adjusted to each job posting so that the keyword overlap is maximized.

If you are sending your resume to hundreds of companies daily, manually editing your resume for each job would be exhausting.

To help job seekers in these difficult times, I've built this app that tailors your resume to a job posting automatically.

Check it out: https://t.co/AUaysofZTg

items.title: @mreflow @boardyai It's an AI that founders of companies talk to on the phone or through chat to hel...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Explains Boardy AI - an AI that helps founders build companies and connects them with matching investors after evaluating both sides
items.reasoning: Interesting AI application for startup ecosystem. Describes AI-mediated matchmaking between founders and investors. Shows real-world agentic AI use case
items.summary_html: Explains Boardy AI - an AI that helps founders build companies and connects them with matching investors after evaluating both sides
items.content_html:
@mreflow @boardyai It's an AI that founders of companies talk to on the phone or through chat to help build their companies and deal with any problems they have. It helps you get your company buffed up enough to be introduced to investors.

Bordy is also talking to thousands of different investors about their fund sizes, their thesis, and their philosophy. When it finds a match between a company and an investor, it calls them up to introduce them.

When I saw this, I immediately thought about having a boss that would call me and tell me it has a job for me. That's sort of what Bordy does.

items.title: @SuchCoolName @TrueEmpireLives @Noahpinion @grok Turns out authoritarian governments will use all me...
items.author: @ylecun
items.summary: Yann LeCun discusses progress in AI hate speech detection (23% in 2017 to 96% in 2022 for Burmese) and criticizes X for not applying similar techniques to current content.
items.reasoning: Technical progress context from Turing Award winner, though primarily political framing.
items.summary_html: Yann LeCun discusses progress in AI hate speech detection (23% in 2017 to 96% in 2022 for Burmese) and criticizes X for not applying similar techniques to current content.
items.content_html:
@SuchCoolName @TrueEmpireLives @Noahpinion @grok Turns out authoritarian governments will use all means of communication to disseminate their hateful propaganda.

The Myanmar government used sock-puppet accounts to incite violence against ethnic and religious minorities. At the time, multilingual AI wasn't good enough to detect hate speech in Burmese. This changed a few years later with progress in NLP and self supervised learning. The percentage of hate speech preemptively detected and suppressed by AI went from 23% in 2017 to 96% in 2022.

Now the Trump government is using X to rile up the population against immigrants and other minorities, and X is doing exactly *nothing* about it.

items.title:
Engineering teams are not shifting from chatbots to voice AI because it is shiny.

I explore how the...
items.content:
Engineering teams are not shifting from chatbots to voice AI because it is shiny.

I explore how they are shifting because fragmentation is killing performance.

One tool for Automatic Speech Recognition. Another for Text-to-Speech. Another for workflows. Another for analytics.

Every hop adds latency, cost, and failure points.

The future is a single real-time system that listens, reasons, and acts ‚Äî a shift companies like @elevenlabsio are enabling.

Here is the shift no team can afford to ignore. 

#ElevenlabsPartner
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon

Engineering teams are not shifting from chatbots to voice AI because it is shiny.

I explore how they are shifting because fragmentation is killing performance.

One tool for Automatic Speech Recognition. Another for Text-to-Speech. Another for workflows. Another for analytics.

Every hop adds latency, cost, and failure points.

The future is a single real-time system that listens, reasons, and acts ‚Äî a shift companies like @elevenlabsio are enabling.

Here is the shift no team can afford to ignore.

items.title:
The shift to autonomous enterprise starts with a mindset reset.

AI is no longer about task augmenta...
items.content:
The shift to autonomous enterprise starts with a mindset reset.

AI is no longer about task augmentation, it is about role transformation.

We are moving from:

‚Ä¢ People supported by tools
to
‚Ä¢ Personas augmented and partially offloaded to AI agents

This demands that organizations rethink strategy, structure, and culture together.
Not one at a time.
